title-group.article-title: Associations of socioeconomic status and health lifestyles with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: two nationwide population-based studies

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Low socioeconomic status (SES) is associated with increased chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) risk, with smoking and poor diet as major contributing factors. However, the impact of a comprehensive healthy lifestyle as a potential mediator between SES and COPD risk remains understudied.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This study analyzed data from 32,836 US adults in the NHANES (1999–2020) and 131,872 UK adults in the UK Biobank. SES was assessed via latent class analysis based on income, education, employment, and health insurance (NHANES). SES was categorized into high, middle, and low levels. Healthy lifestyle scores included nonsmoking, no heavy drinking, regular physical activity, and a high-quality diet. Weighted multivariable logistic regression (NHANES) and Cox proportional hazards models (UK Biobank) were used to assess the associations between SES and the prevalence (NHANES) or incidence (UK Biobank) of COPD.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In the UK Biobank, the incidences of newly diagnosed COPD in the high-, medium-, and low-SES groups were 1.27%, 2.92%, and 6.57%, respectively. In the U.S. NHANES, the prevalence rates of COPD were 2.55%, 2.53%, and 4.50%, respectively. Compared with the highest SES group, a low SES was a risk factor for both the incidence and prevalence of COPD (UK Biobank: HR = 3.27, 95% CI = 2.98 to 3.58; NHANES: OR = 1.61, 95% CI = 1.23 to 2.10). The percentages of the mediation effect of a healthy lifestyle in the UK Biobank and US NHANES were 2.81% and 37.27%, respectively. Additionally, compared with those in the group with the highest SES and the healthiest lifestyle, the risk of COPD incidence and prevalence increased by 950% (HR = 10.50, 95% CI = 9.04 to 12.20) and 641% (OR = 7.41, 95% CI = 5.10 to 10.78), respectively, in the group with the lowest SES and the unhealthiest lifestyle. Risk factor analysis for COPD revealed that, in addition to a low SES (HR = 2.55, 95% CI = 2.39 to 2.72; OR = 2.08, 95% CI = 1.76 to 2.46) and unhealthy lifestyle (HR = 2.92, 95% CI = 2.73 to 3.12; OR = 3.78, 95% CI = 3.13 to 4.57), smoking (HR = 5.23, 95% CI = 4.87 to 5.61; OR = 3.85, 95% CI = 3.23 to 4.59) was the most significant risk factor for COPD.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Low SES significantly contributes to COPD risk, but a healthy lifestyle mediating this association. Promoting healthy lifestyle choices and addressing socioeconomic disparities are essential public health strategies for COPD prevention. Additionally, smoking cessation and increased early screening in smokers are strongly recommended.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s12889-025-23568-5.

institution-wrap.institution: Natural Science Foundation of Liaoning Province
National Natural Science Foundation of China

custom-meta.meta-value: © BioMed Central Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a major cause of death and disability worldwide [ 1 ]. According to World Health Organization (WHO) data, COPD is the third leading cause of death globally, resulting in 3.23 million deaths in 2019 [ 2 ]. As COPD progresses, patients often experience increasing limitations in daily activities due to breathing difficulties [ 3 ]. These difficulties not only impact daily life but can also lead to reduced productivity and higher caregiving and medical costs, placing a significant economic burden on families and society. Research has shown that COPD will cause a loss of $4.326 trillion in the global economy from 2020 to 2050, equivalent to 0.111% of the global GDP [ 4 ].

Compared with other diseases with similar or lower incidence and mortality rates, public and private sector investments in promoting the understanding of COPD, reducing known risks, and developing new treatments have been significantly inadequate in terms of financial and intellectual resources [5]. COPD is typically caused by exposure to inhaled particles, such as cigarette smoke and air pollutants, along with genetic, developmental, and social factors [6].

Socioeconomic status (SES), a measure of a person’s overall socioeconomic level, has been shown to be associated with the incidence and mortality [7] of various chronic noncommunicable diseases, such as diabetes [8] and cardiovascular diseases [7]particularly in individuals with low SES. Previous studies have shown that social class, education level, and residential deprivation can independently affect forced expiratory volume (FEV1) and that individuals with a lower SES tend to have poorer lung function than those with higher SES [9].

A healthy lifestyle, including not smoking, avoiding excessive alcohol consumption, maintaining a high-quality diet, and engaging in regular physical activity, is widely recognized as playing a crucial role in the prevention of various chronic noncommunicable diseases [10] [11]. In studies on COPD prevention, smoking cessation [12] and maintaining a healthy diet [13] have been shown to be beneficial. However, comprehensive evaluations of the association between an overall healthy lifestyle and COPD, as well as its impact on the disease, are lacking.

This study aims to further explore the relationship between comprehensive SES and COPD via large-sample data from multiple countries and to examine whether a healthy lifestyle plays a role in this association.

sec.title: Study population
sec.p: The UK Biobank is a large-scale biomedical database and research resource aimed at improving human health, containing detailed genetic, health, and lifestyle information from 500,000 volunteers aged 40 to 69 years. Among the 502,419 adult participants in the UK, we first excluded 150 pregnant women and 5,500 participants with a history of COPD. We then further excluded 78,033, 248,208, and 38,656 participants due to a lack of socioeconomic information, lifestyle-related data, or other covariates or loss to follow-up. Thus, 131,872 eligible participants remained (Supplementary Fig. 1). All UK Biobank participants provided informed consent, and the project underwent rigorous ethical review to ensure compliance with the highest ethical and legal standards (Project IDs: 98937 and 206612).

The US National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) is a complex, weighted, stratified, multistage sampling study. We used data from 107,622 individuals from 1999 to 2020. We first excluded 48,878 children and adolescents under 20 years of age and then excluded 1,575 pregnant participants, 45,331 participants whose SES information was missing, 18,399 participants whose health lifestyle-related data were missing, 8 participants whose COPD diagnosis information was missing, and 492 participants whose other covariates were missing. Finally, 32,836 participants were included in the COPD analysis (Supplementary Fig. 2). The NHANES study protocol was approved by the Ethics Review Committee of the National Center for Health Statistics, and all participants provided written informed consent, allowing their data to be used for health-related research.

sec.title: Assessment of socioeconomic status
sec.p: SES [7] was assessed on the basis of education level, income, employment status, and health insurance (in the US NHANES). In the UK Biobank, education was categorized as high-level (university or college degree), medium-level (A-level/AS-level or equivalent, O-level/GCSE or equivalent, CSE or equivalent, NVQ or HND or HNC or equivalent, other professional qualifications such as nursing or teaching), or low-level (none of the above) education. Income was categorized as <£18,000, £18,000–£51,999, and ≥£52,000. Employment status included employed (paid work or self-employed, retired, unpaid or voluntary work, or full-time or part-time student) and unemployed (looking after family, unable to work due to illness or disability, unemployed, or none of the above). In the US NHANES, education was categorized as less than high school, high school or equivalent, or more than high school. Income was categorized into three levels on the basis of the family poverty income ratio: ≤1, 1–4, and ≥ 4. Employment status was classified as employed or unemployed. Insurance status was divided into uninsured, public insurance, and private insurance. We used latent class analysis (LCA) from the R package “poLCA” to create a composite SES variable, identifying three latent classes representing high, medium, and low SESs on the basis of education level, income, and employment status.

sec.title: Outcome definition
sec.p: In the UK Biobank, COPD incidence data were obtained from hospital admissions and mortality records using the codes ICD-9 and ICD-10. In the US NHANES, participants were classified as having COPD if they had a prior diagnosis of COPD or if their first measurement of FEV1/FVC was < 0.7 and their second measurement after using a bronchodilator was still < 0.7 [14].

sec.title: Covariates
sec.p: We constructed a healthy lifestyle score based on smoking, alcohol consumption, physical activity, and diet, following previous research [7] and the WHO’s recommendations [15]. Each healthy behaviour was assigned 1 point (healthy level) or 0 points (unhealthy level), resulting in a cumulative healthy lifestyle score ranging from 0 to 4 points, with higher scores indicating a healthier lifestyle. Specifically, the factors contributing to a healthy lifestyle were smoking (healthy level: never smoked, smoked fewer than 100 cigarettes in a lifetime), alcohol consumption [16] (healthy level: ≤2 drinks per day for men, ≤ 1 drink per day for women), healthy physical activity (UK Biobank: defined as at least 150 min of moderate-intensity physical activity per week or at least 75 min of vigorous-intensity physical activity per week; NHANES: total population Metabolic Equivalents (METs) in the top third), and a healthy diet. In the UK Biobank, a healthy diet was defined as meeting five out of seven recommended intakes, which included fruits, vegetables, whole grains, fish, dairy products, plant oils, refined grains, processed meat, unprocessed meat, and sugary drinks (Supplementary Table 1). In the NHANES, a Healthy Eating Index (HEI) [17] in the top 2/5 was considered a healthy diet. The healthy lifestyle score was further divided into three groups: 0–1 points, 2 points, and 3–4 points.

Other covariates included age, sex (male or female), race (UK Biobank: white and nonwhite; NHANES: non-Hispanic white and others), body mass index (BMI), and acculturation score (in the UK Biobank, no information on the language used at home was collected). Therefore, the acculturation score was constructed based on country of birth and length of residence in the UK; scores ranged from 0 to 3, with 3 points for being born in the UK, 2 points for being foreign-born and living in the UK ≥ 20 years, 1 point for being foreign-born and living in the UK for years, and 0 points for being foreign-born and living in the UK for < 10 years. In the US NHANES, a 5-point acculturation score was constructed based on country of birth, length of residence in the US, and language spoken at home. The country of birth and length of residence in the US contributed 3 points, with 3 points for being US-born, 2 points for being foreign-born and living in the US ≥ 20 years, 1 point for being foreign-born and living in the US for 10–19 years, and 0 points for being foreign-born and living in the US for < 10 years. Language spoken at home contributed 2 points, with 2 points for speaking only English or mostly English, 1 point for speaking both equally, and 0 points for speaking only or mostly other languages. The participants were classified into two categories: 0–1 points and 2–3 points. Additional covariates included family history of COPD (UK Biobank only) and history of comorbidities (including cardiovascular disease and cancer).

In the UK Biobank, sleep patterns and air pollution levels were further adjusted. The calculation of sleep patterns [18] incorporated five sleep factors (type of sleep, duration, insomnia, snoring, and daytime sleepiness) to generate a healthy sleep score. For each sleep factor, participants classified as low risk received a score of 1; otherwise, the score was 0. Unhealthy sleep patterns were defined as having a total score of ≤ 1 for the combined sleep pattern score. The calculation of the air pollution score (APS) [19] [20] included PM2.5, coarse PM, PM10, NO2, and NOx, which were derived from the summation of their weighted concentrations. The weighted coefficients were extracted from multivariable-adjusted risk estimates of individual air pollutants. The APS values were then stratified into tertiles.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Continuous variables used to describe baseline characteristics are expressed as the means (standard deviations), whereas categorical variables are presented as numbers (percentages). The Wilcoxon nonparametric test and the χ² test were used to assess relationships between continuous and categorical variables and SES. The UK Biobank is a prospective cohort study, in which Cox regression was used to estimate hazard ratios (HRs). In contrast, NHANES is a nationally representative, cross-sectional health survey with a multistage complex sampling design; therefore, weighted multivariable logistic regression was employed to calculate odds ratios (ORs). Model 1 was adjusted for sex, age, BMI, race, acculturation, family history of COPD (UK Biobank only), and comorbidities. Model 2 was further adjusted for healthy lifestyle score. Additionally, in the UK Biobank dataset, we further corrected for sleep patterns and air pollution levels. We hypothesized that a healthy lifestyle may mediate the relationship between SES and the incidence and prevalence of COPD. Mediation analysis was conducted using the “mediation” package in R. A linear regression model was employed to assess the relationship between the independent variables and the mediator (healthy lifestyle). For the relationship between the mediator and the outcome, weighted logistic regression (NHANES) and Cox regression (UK Biobank) models were used, depending on the nature of the outcome variable.

In the joint association analysis, participants were further classified into nine groups based on SES (low, medium, and high) and healthy lifestyle score (0 or 1 point; 2 points; 3 or 4 points). We estimated the incidence of COPD events in different SES groups, using participants with high SES and a healthy lifestyle score of 3–4 points as the reference group. Additionally, we used participants with a healthy lifestyle score of 0–1 points as the reference to examine the effects of different healthy lifestyles on COPD. Furthermore, we analysed individual risk factors for COPD, adjusting for sex and age, while other risk factor variables were adjusted for sex and age. To quantify the effect of each risk factor, interaction terms were used to evaluate the interactions between SES and sex, obesity, race, family history of COPD, and comorbidities on the incidence and prevalence of COPD. The statistically significant interaction terms suggested the presence of interaction effects.

We performed several sensitivity analyses to ensure the robustness of the results. First, we used multiple imputation to handle missing covariates in the UK Biobank and U.S. NHANES datasets to minimize the potential impact of missing data. Second, to exclude the influence of major diseases on SES and lifestyle, we excluded individuals with comorbidities. Third, we did not use latent class analysis; instead, we defined education and income levels as low, medium, and high, assigning scores of 2, 1, and 0, respectively. Employment status was defined as employed or unemployed (scored as 0 or 1). In the US NHANES, we assigned scores of 2, 1, and 0 for uninsured, public insurance, and private insurance, respectively. We calculated an SES score ranging from 0 to 5 (0 to 7 in the US) and used this score in the model analysis. Finally, in the US NHANES, we included only individuals aged ≥ 40 years to align the population characteristics with those of the UK Biobank.

All analyses were conducted via R software version 4.3.3, and a p value of < 0.05 was considered to indicate statistical significance. All values are reported to two decimal places, with p values < 0.001 expressed directly.

sec.title: Population characteristics
sec.p: In the UK Biobank, a total of 131,872 participants were included in the final analysis of COPD, with follow-up initiated in 2006 and ongoing at the time of analysis. In the NHANES dataset from the United States, which covered the period from 1999 to 2020, a total of 32,836 participants were included in the final analysis of COPD.

Table 1 presents the basic characteristics of the populations included in the COPD analysis in the UK and US datasets. UK Biobank participants had a mean age of 56.19 years and were predominantly White (95.91%). Over half had medium-level educational attainment (53.30%) and reported annual household incomes between £18,000 and £51,999 (53.64%). The majority were employed (93.52%). NHANES participants had a mean age of 47.17 years, with Non-Hispanic Whites comprising the largest racial/ethnic group (72.50%). Most participants were married (64.80%) and had attained more than a high school level of education (63.80%). Nearly half had a poverty income ratio between 1 and 4 (48.20%), and the majority were covered by private health insurance (69.00%).

caption.p: Baseline characteristics of COPD participants according to different socioeconomic statuses in the UK biobank and US NHANES

table-wrap-foot.p: Abbreviation: BMI: Body Mass Index; COPD: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease; NHANES: National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey; SES: Socioeconomic Status
*For continuous variables, we represent them as mean (standard deviation), while categorical variables are expressed as counts (percentages)
p-difference represents the p-value for differences, where continuous variables are compared using the Kruskal-Wallis rank sum test, and categorical variables are assessed using the Chi-squared test
p for trend represents the p-value for trend; in this case, we convert categorical variables into numeric variables and use a linear regression model to evaluate the trend between the variables

sec.p: In the UK Biobank, the incidence rates of newly diagnosed COPD in the high-, middle-, and low-SES groups were 1.27%, 2.92%, and 6.57%, respectively (p for trend < 0.001). In the US NHANES, the prevalence rates of COPD in the high-, middle-, and low-SES groups were 2.55%, 2.53%, and 4.50%, respectively (p for trend < 0.001). Additionally, the proportion of individuals with an unhealthy lifestyle (i.e., those with a healthy lifestyle score of 0–1 points) increased as SES decreased. In the UK Biobank, the proportions of individuals with unhealthy lifestyles in the high-, middle-, and low-SES groups were 13.51%, 17.09%, and 16.68%, respectively (p for trend < 0.001); in the US NHANES, the proportions were 16.60%, 24.20%, and 35.80%, respectively (p for trend < 0.001).

sec.title: Logistic, cox and mediation analyses
sec.p: Table 2, which is based on the results from Cox and logistic regression, shows that low SES is a risk factor for the incidence and prevalence of COPD (UK Biobank: HR = 3.27, 95% CI = 2.98 to 3.58; NHANES: OR = 1.61, 95% CI = 1.23 to 2.10) compared with high SES after adjusting for all covariates. Additionally, medium SES was also a risk factor for COPD incidence (HR = 1.80, 95% CI = 1.64 to 1.97) in the UK Biobank compared with high SES. In both the UK and US datasets, a healthy lifestyle mediated the relationships between SES and COPD incidence and prevalence by 2.81% (95% CI = 2.21–3.50%) and 37.27% (95% CI = 30.37–47.00%), respectively.

caption.p: Associations of socioeconomic status with risk of COPD and the mediating role of a healthy lifestyle

table-wrap-foot.p: Abbreviations: est: estimated effect; SES: Socioeconomic status; CI: confidence interval
Est*: In the UK Biobank analysis, the estimated effect is expressed as an Hazard ratio (HR). Similarly, in the US NHANES analysis, the effect estimate is also presented as an odds ratio (OR)

Note: SES was generated based on information on household income, education level, employment status, and health insurance (for US NHANES only). All models included age, sex, marital status (for US NHANES only), body mass index, self-reported race, acculturation, study center (for UK Biobank), and prevalent comorbidities. The UK Biobank further adjusted for healthy sleep patterns and air pollution levels. The healthy lifestyle score consisted of never smoking, no heavy alcohol consumption, higher physical activity level, and a higher diet quality score

sec.p: The joint effect analysis shown in Table 3 shows when the group with the highest SES and the healthiest lifestyle (3–4 points) were used as the reference, individuals with the lowest SES and the unhealthiest lifestyle (0–1 point) in the UK Biobank and US NHANES had 950% (HR = 10.50, 95% CI = 9.04 to 12.20) and 641% (OR = 7.41, 95% CI = 5.10 to 10.78) increased risks of COPD incidence, respectively.

caption.p: The joint impact of healthy lifestyle score and socioeconomic status on the incidence and prevalence of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

table-wrap-foot.p: Note: SES was generated based on information on household income, education level, employment status, and health insurance (for US NHANES only). All models included age, sex, marital status (for US NHANES only), body mass index, self-reported race, acculturation, study center (for UK Biobank), and prevalent comorbidities. The UK Biobank further adjusted for healthy sleep patterns and air pollution levels. The healthy lifestyle score consisted of never smoking, no heavy alcohol consumption, higher physical activity level, and a higher diet quality score. Each healthy behavior was defined as 1, while unhealthy behaviors were defined as 0. The total score, ranging from 0 to 4, was calculated by summing the scores of the four lifestyle factors, with a higher score indicating a healthier lifestyle

sec.p: The results in Supplementary Table 2 show that, compared with individuals with a healthy lifestyle score of 0–1, both moderate and healthiest lifestyles have a protective effect. This finding is consistent for both the UK Biobank (after adjusting for SES: healthy lifestyle score of 2: HR = 0.55, 95% CI = 0.51 to 0.59; healthy lifestyle score of 3–4: HR = 0.28, 95% CI = 0.25 to 0.30) and the US NHANES (after adjusting for SES: healthy lifestyle score of 2: OR = 0.38, 95% CI = 0.31to 0.46; healthy lifestyle score of 3–4: OR = 0.22, 95% CI = 0.17 to 0.29).

Supplementary Table 3 further illustrates the associations between socioeconomic indicators and specific healthy lifestyle components. In both the UK Biobank and US NHANES, lower educational attainment, low income, and unemployment were significantly associated with reduced likelihood of engaging in healthy behaviors, such as non-smoking and adherence to a healthy diet. Additionally, in the UK Biobank, lower socioeconomic indicators were associated with a higher likelihood of abstaining from alcohol. In contrast, in the NHANES study, lower socioeconomic status was identified as a risk factor for lower levels of physical activity. Moreover, lack of insurance was inversely associated with non-smoking, higher physical activity, and adherence to a healthy diet.

sec.title: Risk factor analysis
sec.p: Figure 1 demonstrates the risk factor analyses from both the UK Biobank and the US NHANES, revealing remarkably consistent trends between the two cohorts. The analyses identified that low socioeconomic status (UK Biobank: HR = 2.55, 95% CI = 2.39–2.72; NHANES: OR = 2.08, 95% CI = 1.76–2.46) and unhealthy lifestyle (defined as a healthy lifestyle score of 0–1; UK Biobank: HR = 2.92, 95% CI = 2.73–3.12; NHANES: OR = 3.78, 95% CI = 3.23–4.59) were significant risk factors for both COPD incidence and prevalence. Notably, current smoking status demonstrated particularly strong associations (UK Biobank: HR = 5.23, 95% CI = 4.87–5.61; NHANES: OR = 3.85, 95% CI = 3.23–4.59).

caption.p: Associations between risk factors and the incidence and prevalence of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease based on analyses from the UK Biobank and the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey

sec.p: Among the components of socioeconomic status, unemployment emerged as the most prominent risk factor (UK Biobank: HR = 3.38, 95% CI = 3.07–3.72; NHANES: OR = 2.21, 95% CI = 1.79–2.73), followed by low income (UK Biobank: HR = 2.46, 95% CI = 2.30–2.63; NHANES: OR = 1.70, 95% CI = 1.38–2.10) and low education level (UK Biobank: HR = 2.30, 95% CI = 2.11–2.50; NHANES: OR = 1.57, 95% CI = 1.34–1.85). Interestingly, lack of health insurance coverage did not show significant association with COPD prevalence in the NHANES cohort.

sec.title: Interaction, subgroup, and sensitivity analyses
sec.p: The interaction analyses in Supplementary Tables 4 and 5 both indicate that comorbidities interact with SES in relation to COPD (UK Biobank: p-interaction < 0.001; NHANES: p-interaction = 0.04). Additionally, in the U.S. NHANES dataset, the risk of COPD associated with low SES was more pronounced among individuals with comorbidities.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we utilized large datasets from the United States and the United Kingdom to compare the mediating effects of SES and healthy lifestyle on the impact of COPD via a latent class model. The resultant findings indicate that low SES is a risk factor for both the incidence and prevalence of COPD. Compared with individuals with the highest SES and the healthiest lifestyles, the risk of developing and being diagnosed with COPD increased by 950% and 641%, respectively, among those with the lowest SES and the least healthy lifestyles. These results highlight the significant influence of social structure and healthy lifestyle on the incidence and prevalence of COPD.

The relationship between SES inequality and COPD has been widely discussed. A study involving low- and middle-income countries revealed an association between low SES and the risk of COPD, with lower levels of education, household income, and SES indices all linked to COPD incidence [21]. A prospective study using data from the China Kadoorie Biobank project also revealed that SES is associated with the risk of COPD in Chinese adults [11].

The mechanisms underlying the relationship between COPD and SES are not yet fully understood. However, this relationship appears to be related to greater access to health resources among individuals with higher SES [22]. Overall, people with high SES tend to have higher income, education levels, and higher employment rates, and in the U.S., they are more likely to have private insurance. Individuals with high SES often have better health literacy, which corresponds to a stronger ability to understand and apply health information [23] [24]. As noted by the World Health Organization, health literacy is a crucial determinant of health and is closely linked to population life expectancy and overall health status [25]. In our study, we found that unemployment is the most significant risk factor within SES, and this association remains consistent in both the UK Biobank and NHANES. Research has shown that unstable or even low-quality employment can impact mental health [26] [27]and a study conducted among farmers revealed that poor mental health is associated with an increased risk of COPD [28].

Individuals with low SES are more likely to adopt unhealthy lifestyles [29]. In our study, we similarly found that low education, low income, unemployment, and lack of health insurance were associated with a lower prevalence of healthy lifestyle behaviors, including non-smoking, physical activity, and a healthy diet. Additionally, in the UK Biobank dataset, lower levels of specific socioeconomic indicators were associated with an increased likelihood of alcohol abstinence. This phenomenon has also been observed in previous studies [30] and may be related to higher levels of stress [31]and reduced alcohol availability [32] among individuals with low SES. Additionally, low-SES residents are more likely to be exposed to environmental tobacco smoke, use nonclean fuels for cooking and heating, live in poorly ventilated homes, and prefer to cook themselves [33] [34]. The lack of clean household fuels and inadequate kitchen ventilation can lead to indoor air pollution, which has been identified as a significant factor increasing the risk of COPD in women [35] [36].

This study is the first to explore the role of a healthy lifestyle in the association between SES and COPD. Previous studies have examined the benefits of a healthy diet and nonsmoking status [37] for COPD patients. A healthy and balanced diet has been proven to be associated with better lung function, less lung function decline, and a reduced risk of COPD [13] [38]. Alcohol consumption is associated with the deterioration of COPD [39]whereas regular physical activity helps slow its progression [40]. This study further confirms that individuals with a healthy lifestyle score of 0–1 face significant risks regarding COPD. In addition to its impact on the progression of COPD in patients, alcohol consumption and a lack of adequate physical activity have also been identified as important risk factors for both the incidence and prevalence of COPD. Nevertheless, further clinical trials and large-scale cohort studies are needed to validate these findings and explore the underlying mechanisms in greater depth.

The findings of this study indicate several potential policy implications. First, targeted interventions such as smoking cessation support, free or low-cost physical activity programs, and nutrition education should be prioritized for individuals with low SES. Second, integrating social support services—such as employment assistance—into primary healthcare systems may help address upstream determinants of health. Finally, region-specific public awareness campaigns aimed at increasing knowledge of COPD risk factors among low-SES populations should be implemented, with culturally and linguistically tailored materials to ensure accessibility and relevance.

Moreover, both the low SES groups in the United States and the United Kingdom generally have lower levels of education, lower income, and higher unemployment rates. Therefore, it is recommended to implement more educational opportunities and vocational training programs for these populations. In addition, while the United States’ SES framework further considers health insurance, with low SES groups primarily relying on public insurance or being uninsured, the United Kingdom, despite having universal healthcare coverage, still faces significant health disparities within its low SES populations. Thus, it is suggested that the United States further expand public health insurance coverage, while in the United Kingdom, there is a need to strengthen health management support for low SES groups.

This study has the following strengths. First, we utilized two large databases from the United Kingdom and the United States, which yielded largely consistent results. The large sample size allowed us to conduct combined and stratified analyses with sufficient statistical power. Furthermore, stratifying SES based on the LCA model better reflects the comprehensive nature of SES. We also conducted several sensitivity analyses to demonstrate the robustness of the results and to assess the impact of individual socioeconomic and lifestyle factors. Moreover, different populations and larger sample sizes can further confirm the risks associated with low SES. Inclusion of diverse cohorts, particularly from developing countries and resource-limited settings, allows robust validation of the association between low SES and COPD risk across healthcare systems and cultural contexts. A larger sample size enables refined subgroup analyses (e.g., by treatment adherence), informing targeted tertiary prevention strategies.

However, this study has several limitations. First, information on SES and healthy lifestyle was primarily self-reported and measured only once, which inevitably introduces measurement error. Second, the construction of SES variables varied across the two databases. For example, in the US study, health insurance plans were included as a component, but this factor was not considered in the UK dataset because of the implementation of universal health coverage policies in the UK. Third, the lifestyle score was based on the number of healthy lifestyle factors, assuming that all lifestyle factors had the same impact on health outcomes. However, our analysis revealed that not all healthy lifestyle factors equally affect health outcomes, particularly the significant risk of smoking for COPD. Fourth, individuals diagnosed with COPD during the study period may have had other serious conditions at baseline, which could influence lifestyle behaviours and SES. Although our primary analysis adjusted for baseline comorbidities and the sensitivity analyses excluded individuals with major chronic diseases at baseline, residual confounding factors (from unmeasured or unconsidered diseases) and reverse causality cannot be completely ruled out. Fifth, individuals excluded from the analysis because of missing covariates and nonresponses were more likely to belong to the low SES group, which may lead to an underestimation of socioeconomic inequalities in health outcomes. Finally, although we controlled for key individual characteristics and comorbidities, residual confounding factors may still exist, and causal inference cannot be established due to the observational nature of the study.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion, populations with low SES face significantly greater risks for both the incidence and prevalence of COPD. A healthy lifestyle also plays a mediating role in this relationship. Compared with individuals with high SES and the healthiest lifestyle, those with low SES and the unhealthiest lifestyle have a substantially increased risk of COPD incidence and prevalence. Future COPD prevention interventions need to consider both SES and healthy lifestyle factors. Additionally, focused efforts to reduce smoking, enforce anti-smoking policies, and improve early COPD screening in smoking populations are essential.

ack.p: This research was conducted using the UK Biobank Resource under Application Number 98973 and 206612.

notes.title: Author contributions
notes.p: YZL, JZ, and QQG are joint corresponding authors. YZL, BXY, and SYL conceived and designed the study. QQG, JL, CHL and JHG supervised the study. SYL, TTL, CHL, HYW, JHG, and BXY performed the statistical analysis. All authors contributed to acquisition, analysis, or interpretation of data. SYL, JZ, TTL, QQG and YZL drafted the manuscript. All authors revised the report and approved the final version before submission. YZL is the guarantor and attests that all listed authors meet authorship criteria and that no others meeting the criteria have been omitted.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: This work is supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 82304201 and 82470826), the Liaoning Provincial Science and Technology High-quality Development Project (Grant No. 2023JH2/20200059), and the Joint Funds of the Liaoning Provincial Natural Science Foundation (Grant No. 2023-MSLH-409). The funder of the study had no role in the study design, data collection, data analysis, data interpretation, or the writing of the report. The corresponding author had full access to all the data in the study and had final responsibility for the decision to submit for publication.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: The data were obtained from the UK Biobank and NHANES databases.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: The authors declare no competing interests.

notes.title: Ethics approval and consent to participate
notes.p: All UK Biobank participants provided informed consent, and the project underwent rigorous ethical review to ensure compliance with the highest ethical and legal standards (Project IDs: 98937 and 206612). The NHANES study protocol was approved by the Ethics Review Committee of the National Center for Health Statistics, and all participants provided written informed consent, allowing their data to be used for health-related research.

notes.title: Competing interests
notes.p: All authors declare no competing interests.
